teaching_point: An object at rest will remain at rest unless a force causes it to move.

teaching_point: The more mass an object has, the harder it is to change its motion.

teaching_point: Diffraction is the bending and spreading of waves when they encounter an obstacle or pass through a narrow slit.
visual_explanation: Show a water wave approaching a narrow gap in a barrier. As it passes through, the wavefronts spread out in semicircles beyond the slit, showing clear bending around edges.
explicit_prompt: Show a water wave approaching a narrow gap in a barrier. As the wavefront reaches the gap and passes through, the straight wavefronts transform into semicircular wavefronts that spread out and bend around the edges of the slit, clearly illustrating the phenomenon of diffraction.

multiimage_question.Description1: the straight water wavefront approaches and begins to interact with the narrow gap in the barrier, with the wavefront just starting to enter the slit.
multiimage_question.Description2: the wavefronts that have passed through the gap are now spreading out in semicircles, bending noticeably around the edges, while the unpassed parts remain blocked by the barrier.

visual_prompt: Show a water wave approaching a narrow gap in a barrier. As it passes through, the wavefronts spread out in semicircles beyond the slit, showing clear bending around edges.

teaching_point: The extent of diffraction increases when the slit size is comparable to the wavelength of the wave.
visual_explanation: Display two slits: one wide and one narrow. Shine monochromatic light through both. The narrow slit produces wider and more spread-out diffraction patterns than the wide slit.
explicit_prompt: Display two slits of different widths, one wide and one narrow, with monochromatic light shining through both. The narrow slit produces a broader, more spread-out diffraction pattern compared to the wide slit, illustrating how reducing the slit width (to be comparable to the wavelength) increases the diffraction angle and makes the light spread more.

multiimage_question.Description1: the narrow and wide slits are shown, and monochromatic light passes through each, beginning to form patterns on a screen behind the slits.
multiimage_question.Description2: the diffraction patterns become clearly visible. The pattern from the narrow slit spreads out much more widely on the screen, while the pattern from the wide slit remains more concentrated and narrow.

visual_prompt: Display two slits: one wide and one narrow. Shine monochromatic light through both. The narrow slit produces wider and more spread-out diffraction patterns than the wide slit.

teaching_point: Diffraction causes light to form interference patterns of bright and dark fringes.
visual_explanation: Show a laser beam passing through a single slit and hitting a screen. Display the resulting pattern: a central bright fringe with alternating dark and bright bands on both sides.
explicit_prompt: Show a laser beam passing through a single slit and hitting a screen. As the beam passes through the slit, the light spreads out and interferes with itself, forming a central bright fringe and alternating dark and bright bands on the screen. This demonstrates how diffraction creates interference patterns.

multiimage_question.Description1: the initially uniform laser beam passes through the single slit, and a faint central bright spot begins to appear on the screen.
multiimage_question.Description2: the interference pattern becomes more pronounced, with the central bright fringe and clear alternating dark and bright bands forming on the screen.

visual_prompt: Show a laser beam passing through a single slit and hitting a screen. Display the resulting pattern: a central bright fringe with alternating dark and bright bands on both sides.

teaching_point: A coherent source produces waves that are all the same shape and travel in the same direction.
visual_explanation: A vibrating tuning fork sits on a table. Waves spread away from the fork in circular ripples, growing larger and farther apart as they move outward. The background is a dark room with a simple wooden table. The ripples remain evenly spaced and uniform in shape as they expand.
explicit_prompt: A vibrating tuning fork sits on a table. Waves spread away from the fork in circular ripples, expanding uniformly from a central point. The ripples remain evenly spaced and have the same shape as they move outward, illustrating that a coherent source creates waves that are all the same shape and travel in the same direction.

multiimage_question.Description1: the circular wavefronts around the tuning fork have expanded outward, becoming larger and covering more of the table, but they remain evenly spaced and uniform in shape.
multiimage_question.Description2: the circular wavefronts continue to expand further outward. The spacing and shape of the ripples stay the same, and the waves maintain their uniform pattern as they move away from the tuning fork.

visual_prompt: A vibrating tuning fork sits on a table.  Show waves emanating outwards in all directions from the fork, appearing as circular ripples expanding from a central point. The background is a dark room with a simple wooden table.

teaching_point: An incoherent source produces waves that are different shapes and travel in different directions.
visual_explanation: Multiple objects – a bell, a speaker, and a drum – vibrate simultaneously in a small room. Waves radiate outwards from each object, appearing as chaotic, overlapping circles and irregular patterns spreading throughout the space. The background shows a basic office environment.
explicit_prompt: Multiple objects – a bell, a speaker, and a drum – vibrate simultaneously in a small room. Waves radiate outwards from each object, appearing as chaotic, overlapping circles and irregular patterns spreading throughout the space. The background is a simple office environment. This demonstrates that incoherent sources emit waves with different shapes and directions, leading to a complex, disordered wave pattern in the room.

multiimage_question.Description1: the initially small and faint wave patterns around each vibrating object become larger and more visible, with overlapping and irregular shapes starting to fill the room.
multiimage_question.Description2: the chaotic and irregular wave patterns continue to expand and spread throughout the entire room, with even more overlap and randomness, showing increased complexity in the wave distribution.

visual_prompt: Multiple objects – a bell, a speaker, and a drum – vibrate simultaneously in a small room. Waves radiate outwards from each object, appearing as chaotic, overlapping circles and irregular patterns spreading throughout the space.  The background shows a basic office environment.

teaching_point: Heat engines convert thermal energy into mechanical work.
visual_explanation: A steam locomotive's wheels start turning as steam rises from the engine.
explicit_prompt: A steam locomotive begins to operate as steam is produced in the engine, causing its wheels to start turning. The steam generated from heating water pushes pistons, which in turn rotate the locomotive's wheels, demonstrating the conversion of thermal energy into mechanical work.

multiimage_question.Description1: steam begins to rise from the locomotive, and the wheels start to move, showing the initial conversion of heat to motion.
multiimage_question.Description2: the amount of steam increases and the wheels turn faster, indicating a greater conversion of thermal energy into mechanical work.

visual_prompt: A steam locomotive's wheels start turning as steam rises from the engine.

teaching_point: The efficiency of a heat engine is the ratio of work output to heat input.
visual_explanation: Two identical steam locomotives, one moving faster than the other, while both emit the same amount of steam.
explicit_prompt: Two identical steam locomotives travel along parallel tracks. Both emit the same amount of steam, but one locomotive moves noticeably faster than the other. This demonstrates that, given equal heat input (shown by equal steam emission), the faster locomotive produces more work output, illustrating higher efficiency.

multiimage_question.Description1: both locomotives have moved forward, maintaining the same steam emission, but the faster locomotive has covered more distance than the slower one.
multiimage_question.Description2: the distance between the two locomotives increases further, as the faster locomotive continues to outpace the slower one, with both still emitting the same amount of steam.

visual_prompt: Two identical steam locomotives, one moving faster than the other, while both emit the same amount of steam.

teaching_point: Refrigerators move thermal energy from a cool environment to a warmer one.
visual_explanation: Ice cubes inside a transparent fridge begin to melt while the back of the fridge releases warm air.
explicit_prompt: Ice cubes inside a transparent fridge begin to melt while the back of the fridge releases warm air. As time passes, the ice cubes shrink due to melting, while droplets of water collect nearby. Simultaneously, the back of the fridge emits warm air, showing that heat is moved from inside the fridge to the outside.

multiimage_question.Description1: the ice cubes inside the fridge have become smaller and partially melted, with droplets of water starting to appear near them. The back of the fridge begins to release warm air.
multiimage_question.Description2: the ice cubes have melted further or completely, leaving behind more liquid water, while the back of the fridge continues to release warm air into the surrounding area.

visual_prompt: Ice cubes inside a transparent fridge begin to melt while the back of the fridge releases warm air.

teaching_point: Entropy is a measure of the disorder or randomness in a system.
visual_explanation: Show a box of neatly arranged red and blue balls. Then shake the box — the balls randomly mix and spread out, representing increased disorder.
explicit_prompt: Show a box that initially contains neatly arranged red and blue balls. When the box is shaken, the balls become randomly mixed and spread throughout the box, increasing the disorder. This models how entropy increases as systems become less ordered over time.

multiimage_question.Description1: Initially, the red and balls are neatly arragned and at rest. The balls start to lose their neat arrangement and some begin to mix together, showing the start of increased disorder.
multiimage_question.Description2: the balls become completely mixed and randomly distributed throughout the box, representing maximum disorder.

visual_prompt: Show a box of neatly arranged red and blue balls. Then shake the box — the balls randomly mix and spread out, representing increased disorder.

teaching_point: In natural processes, entropy tends to increase, leading to more disordered states over time.
visual_explanation: Show an ice cube melting into water. The initially ordered structure of the ice transitions into disordered liquid molecules, represented by free-moving particles.
explicit_prompt: Show an ice cube melting into water. The initially ordered structure of the ice transitions into disordered liquid molecules, represented by free-moving particles. As the ice melts, the solid, crystalline arrangement of the molecules becomes a more random, fluid state, illustrating the increase in entropy.

multiimage_question.Description1: The ice cube begins to shrink as it melts, with water pooling around it and the edges appearing less defined. The structure is less ordered than before.
multiimage_question.Description2: The ice cube has fully melted, leaving only liquid water with free-moving particles. The ordered arrangement has disappeared, and the water appears completely disordered.

visual_prompt: Show an ice cube melting into water. The initially ordered structure of the ice transitions into disordered liquid molecules, represented by free-moving particles.

teaching_point: Entropy increases when energy becomes more spread out and less available to do useful work.
visual_explanation: Show hot gas particles in one half of a box. After removing a partition, the gas spreads evenly throughout, symbolizing energy spreading out and becoming less usable.
explicit_prompt: Show hot gas particles initially confined to one half of a box by a partition. When the partition is removed, the gas particles gradually spread out to fill the entire box, representing the spreading out of energy and the increase in entropy.

multiimage_question.Description1: Gas particles are tightly clustered on the left side of a box, separated by a partition.
multiimage_question.Description2: After removing the partition, particles are evenly dispersed throughout the entire box, illustrating increased entropy.

teaching_point: Converging lenses (convex) focus parallel rays of light to a single point known as the focal point.
visual_explanation: Show parallel rays of sunlight entering a clear convex lens. Slowly trace each ray bending inward and meeting at a single bright point on the opposite side, labeled 'F'. Use a zoom-in to emphasize the convergence and lens shape.
explicit_prompt: Show parallel rays of sunlight entering a clear convex lens. As the rays pass through the lens, each one bends inward due to refraction and converges at a single bright point on the far side of the lens, labeled 'F' for focal point. The zoom-in highlights how the rays, which started parallel, are now focused together at one spot, visually demonstrating how a convex lens brings light to a focus.

multiimage_question.Description1: Parallel rays of sunlight approach a convex lens from the left side.
multiimage_question.Description2: After passing through the lens, the rays bend inward and meet at a single point labeled 'F'.

teaching_point: Diverging lenses (concave) spread out parallel rays of light away from a single point.
visual_explanation: Show parallel light rays entering a concave lens. As they pass through, animate each ray bending outward. Extend dotted lines backward behind the lens to intersect at a point labeled 'F'.
explicit_prompt: Show parallel light rays entering a concave (diverging) lens. As the rays pass through the lens, each one bends outward away from the central axis. Behind the lens, extend dotted lines backward from each bent ray so that they meet at a single point labeled 'F', demonstrating that the rays appear to originate from this focal point.

multiimage_question.Description1: the parallel light rays approach and begin to pass through the concave lens.
multiimage_question.Description2: the rays have fully spread out after passing through the lens. Dotted lines are extended backward from the outgoing rays, and they intersect at a point labeled 'F' behind the lens, showing the apparent origin of the diverging rays.

visual_prompt: Show parallel light rays entering a concave lens. As they pass through, animate each ray bending outward. Extend dotted lines backward behind the lens to intersect at a point labeled 'F'.

teaching_point: The image formed by a concave lens is always virtual, upright, and smaller than the object, no matter where the object is placed.
visual_explanation: Place an object (e.g., a candle) in front of a concave lens. Show the principal rays: one parallel (diverges as if from focal point), one toward the center (passes straight). Mark the rays' extensions meeting behind the object to form a small upright virtual image.
explicit_prompt: Place an object, such as a candle, in front of a concave lens. Draw the principal rays: one ray travels from the top of the candle parallel to the principal axis and then diverges outward after passing through the lens, appearing to originate from the focal point on the same side as the object. The second ray passes from the top of the candle straight through the center of the lens without changing direction. Extend the diverged ray backward to meet the undeviated ray—these extensions cross behind the object, forming a small, upright, and virtual image. The image remains upright and smaller than the object, regardless of the object's position.

multiimage_question.Description1: the principal rays from the object are shown passing through the concave lens. The parallel ray diverges after the lens, and the central ray continues straight, with the extensions of the rays being drawn to indicate where they would meet.
multiimage_question.Description2: the extensions of the diverging and straight rays are clearly marked behind the object. A small, upright, virtual image of the object appears at the intersection of these extensions, illustrating that the image is always virtual, upright, and smaller than the object.

visual_prompt: Place an object (e.g., a candle) in front of a concave lens. Show the principal rays: one parallel (diverges as if from focal point), one toward the center (passes straight). Mark the rays' extensions meeting behind the object to form a small upright virtual image.

teaching_point: Resonance occurs when a system is driven by an external force at its natural frequency, leading to large amplitude oscillations.
visual_explanation: Show a child sitting on a swing. Initially, the pushes are irregular, and the swing barely moves. Then, demonstrate the child being pushed at regular intervals matching the swing’s natural back-and-forth motion. With each well-timed push, the swing’s amplitude increases noticeably. Clearly highlight that the energy transfer is most efficient when the pushing frequency matches the swing’s natural frequency.
explicit_prompt: A child sits on a swing. At first, the child receives pushes at random times, so the swing barely gains height and the motion remains small. Later, the child is pushed at the same rhythm as the swing’s natural movement. With each perfectly timed push, the swing’s arc becomes larger and the motion increases noticeably. This demonstrates that pushing at the swing’s natural frequency leads to much larger oscillations due to resonance.

multiimage_question.Retrieval Prompt: Show the frame where the swing first begins to noticeably increase its arc due to well-timed pushes (after the irregular pushes).
multiimage_question.Description1: Between the first frame (where the swing barely moves with irregular pushes) and the retrieval frame (the first frame showing well-timed pushes), the swing’s arc starts to noticeably increase, and the child swings higher than before.
multiimage_question.Description2: Between the retrieval frame (first noticeable increase in arc) and the last frame (after several well-timed pushes), the swing’s arc grows even larger, and the child reaches a much greater height, clearly showing the effect of resonance.

visual_prompt: Show a child sitting on a swing. Initially, the pushes are irregular, and the swing barely moves. Then, demonstrate the child being pushed at regular intervals matching the swing’s natural back-and-forth motion. With each well-timed push, the swing’s amplitude increases noticeably. Clearly highlight that the energy transfer is most efficient when the pushing frequency matches the swing’s natural frequency.

teaching_point: Different systems have different natural frequencies; resonance occurs only when the driving frequency matches the system’s natural frequency.
visual_explanation: Show three identical glass goblets placed side by side, each labeled with a different natural frequency (f₁, f₂, f₃). A nearby speaker emits a sound that gradually sweeps across frequencies. When the sound matches f₂, the middle goblet begins to visibly vibrate, possibly showing cracking or distortion. The other goblets remain unaffected. Use animated wave patterns to visually represent the matching frequencies.
explicit_prompt: Show three identical glass goblets placed side by side, each labeled with a different natural frequency (f₁, f₂, f₃). A nearby speaker emits a sound that gradually sweeps across frequencies. As the sound frequency increases and matches f₂, the middle goblet begins to visibly vibrate, showing signs of resonance. The other goblets remain still. Animated wave patterns on the goblets indicate the matching of frequencies, emphasizing that resonance only occurs when the driving frequency matches the natural frequency of the system.

multiimage_question.Retrieval Prompt: When the sound frequency reaches f₂
multiimage_question.Description1: All three goblets remain still while the sound frequency increases from low to mid range.
multiimage_question.Description2: The middle goblet starts vibrating noticeably as the sound reaches f₂, while the other goblets remain still.
